title: Java - TP3
Java - TP3
Introduction to Java syntax
text:
In this first tutorial, we‚Äôre simply going to familiarize ourselves with Java syntax, without using object-oriented programming.
This is why methods are defined as static. They are class methods. You don‚Äôt need to instantiate an object to call them.
We‚Äôre going to do a few exercises on the subject of passwords.

title: Introduction to Java syntax
text:
In this first tutorial, we‚Äôre simply going to familiarize ourselves with Java syntax, without using object-oriented programming.
This is why methods are defined as static. They are class methods. You don‚Äôt need to instantiate an object to call them.
We‚Äôre going to do a few exercises on the subject of passwords.

title: Introduction to Java syntax
text:
1 Introduction
In this tutorial, we will use the INSEE SSPCloud Datalab.

Login to SSPCloud


1.1 Git setup






Caution



On the datalab, your services have a limited lifespan.
To save your programs, the best practice is to use a git repository. We will therefore create and use a token to communicate with GitHub.
To follow the process, you need to have a GitHub account. It is also possible to follow a similar process with GitLab.



Generate a GitHub Token






Already done?



If you have already generated and declared a GitHub token, there‚Äôs no need to repeat these 2 steps.



Login to GitHub
Go to settings ‚û°Ô∏è Developer settings ‚û°Ô∏è Personal access tokens ‚û°Ô∏è Tokens (classic)
Generate a new classic token

Fill in:

token name: Datalab GENES
expiration date ‚û°Ô∏è Custom ‚û°Ô∏è 1 year

‚úÖ Check the repo box
Click on Generate token
Copy the token starting with ghp_ and keep it safe for a few minutes








Warning




This token will only be visible once
If you lose it or if it expires, you must generate a new one





Declare Your Token
GitHub has provided you with a token. Now, you need to declare it on the Datalab:

Go to My Account ‚û°Ô∏è Git tab
Fill in the following information:

Git username
email (the one used for your GitHub account)

Paste your token







Git Config



You can now exchange code between the Datalab services and your GitHub repositories. üéâ





1.2 Launch Vscode Java
A service is available with Visual Studio Code and Java.

Launch the service VScode-Java







Important



You won‚Äôt find this service in the basic catalog. You have to use the link above to launch it.
It uses a specific Docker image



Back to GitHub, fork this repository: https://github.com/ludo2ne/ENSAI-2A-Java-TP/fork
On the main page of your fork, click on Code
Copy https url to clipboard
Back to VSCode in the Datalab, Clone the forked repository using this https url
In the menu (3 parallel bars top left) ‚û°Ô∏è File ‚û°Ô∏è Open Folder

enter : /home/onyxia/work/ENSAI-2A-Java-TP/ ‚û°Ô∏è OK








Shorcuts




SHIFT + ALT + A: Comment / Uncomment selected lines

title: Introduction to Java syntax
text:
2 Exercices

Open a terminal

Terminal > New Terminal (or CTRL + √π)

Go to the folder ENSAI-2A-Java-TP/tp1/src

if you need help, check out Unix basic commands



Compile

a single Java file: javac MyClass.java
all Java files: javac *.java
specify output directory for .class files (recommended): javac -d bin MyClass.java



Run






Important



To run a class, it must have a main() method.



java MyClass
when .class files are in the bin/ directory: java -cp bin MyClass







Static Methods



As mentioned at the beginning, the aim of this tutorial is not OOP, but simply basic Java syntax.
So all the methods defined here are static ‚û°Ô∏è They are class methods ‚û°Ô∏è They can be called without instantiating an object.




2.1 Brute force
You will write a Java method that attempts to brute-force a hashed 6-digit numeric password.

The method will iterate through all numbers from 000000 to 999999
For each number, Generate and compare hash with the given target hash
If a match is found, return the original number else return null



Open File Password.java
Complete method bruteForce6Digit()







Tip




Use method hashPassword()
String.format("%06d", 123)‚û°Ô∏è ‚Äú000123‚Äù





2.2 Strong password

Commit and Push the code of the last exercise
Complete method isStrongPassword()

You will write a Java method to check if a password is strong. A password is strong if:

‚úÖ It has at least 12 characters
‚úÖ It contains at least one uppercase letter
‚úÖ It contains at least one lowercase letter
‚úÖ It contains at least one digit
‚ùå It does not contain whitespace







Tip



Usefull methods:

Character.isUpperCase(<char>)
Character.isDigit(<char>)
Character.isWhitespace(<char>)





2.3 Check password list

Commit and Push the code of the last exercise
Complete method checkPasswordsList()

You will write a method that takes a list of passwords (ArrayList) and checks their strength.
The method should return a HashMap where:

The keys are the passwords
The values are true if the password is strong, false otherwise



2.4 Generate a Random Password
Objective: Implement a method to generate a secure random password that includes at least:

‚úÖ 1 uppercase letter

‚úÖ 1 lowercase letter

‚úÖ 1 digit

‚úÖ 1 special character


Ensure length is at least 4
Create a list of characters
Add at least one character from each group

Fill the remaining characters randomly from all groups
Shuffle the password to mix character types Collections.shuffle(<myList>)
Convert the list into a String and return it


Complete method generatePassword()







Generate random int between 0 and 20



SecureRandom random = new SecureRandom();
System.out.println(random.nextInt(21));




2.5 Login System
Complete file Login.java:

Loads csv file data/user_hashpwd.csv containing usernames and hashed passwords
Ask for a username
If username exists, ask for password
If login succeeds, print Login successful! and exit, else ask again username

Bonus:

After entering username, give 3 chances to input the correct password
If all 3 attempts fail, restart username input







Use a Scanner



Scanner scanner = new Scanner(System.in);

System.out.print("Enter username: ");
String username = scanner.nextLine();

scanner.close();

title: Collections
text:
Three main types to store and manage data:

List
Map
Set

Each serves a different purpose.

title: Collections
text:

Set

title: Collections
Collections
Collections
Collections
section: Choosing Between List, Set, and Map
text:
Choosing Between List, Set, and Map



Feature
ArrayList
HashSet
HashMap




Allows Duplicates?
‚úÖ
‚ùå
‚ùå (Keys)


Maintains Order?
‚úÖ
‚ùå
‚ùå


Key-Value Storage?
‚ùå
‚ùå
‚úÖ


Fast Lookup?
‚ùå O(n)
‚úÖ O(1)
‚úÖ O(1)



üëâ Use a List when order matters and duplicates are allowed.
üëâ Use a Set when uniqueness is required.
üëâ Use a Map when you need key-value storage.

title: Collections
text:
Collections in Java
Three main types to store and manage data:

List
Map
Set

Each serves a different purpose.

title: Collections
text:
ArrayList

Ordered
Allow duplicates
Fast for reading, slow for searching
Slow for inserting/deleting in the middle


LinkedList (Fast for inserting/deleting, slower for accessing elements)

title: Collections
text:
HashMap

HashMap<K, V>
associate a key (K) with a value (V)
Unordered
Fast access



like python dict
others:

TreeMap: Sorted by key
LinkedHashMap: Maintains insertion order

title: Collections
Collections
section: Choosing Between List, Set, and Map
text:
Choosing Between List, Set, and Map



Feature
ArrayList
HashSet
HashMap




Allows Duplicates?
‚úÖ
‚ùå
‚ùå (Keys)


Maintains Order?
‚úÖ
‚ùå
‚ùå


Key-Value Storage?
‚ùå
‚ùå
‚úÖ


Fast Lookup?
‚ùå O(n)
‚úÖ O(1)
‚úÖ O(1)



üëâ Use a List when order matters and duplicates are allowed.
üëâ Use a Set when uniqueness is required.
üëâ Use a Map when you need key-value storage.

title: Java Basics
text:
First of all






Important


In Java, all executable code must be inside a class.

title: Java Basics
Java Basics
Java Basics
text:
Variables and Data Types
int age = 25;
final double PI = 3.14;        // final : Immutable

boolean isJavaFun = true;

char grade = 'A';             // single quote
String name = "L√©a";          // double quote

var i = 2F;                   // type inference -> float


strong typing, immuable type
primitive, object
String

not a primitive data type
String is a Class
immutable: Any modification creates a new string in memory

title: Java Basics
Java Basics
Java Basics
text:
Variables and Data Types
int age = 25;
final double PI = 3.14;        // final : Immutable

boolean isJavaFun = true;

char grade = 'A';             // single quote
String name = "L√©a";          // double quote

var i = 2F;                   // type inference -> float


strong typing, immuable type
primitive, object
String

not a primitive data type
String is a Class
immutable: Any modification creates a new string in memory




Boolean
boolean isJavaFun = true;
boolean hasBrother = false;

boolean isFast = 20 > 15;

isJavaFun && !false || true;


lowercase booleans
No need for == true




String
String myString = "Java";
String fullName = "Alain" + " " + "Philippe";   // concat

myString.length();
myString.charAt(0);          // Get character at index 0
myString.contains("va");
myString.toLowerCase();      // also toUpperCase
myString.endsWith("Java");   // also startsWith

myString.equals("Java");     // Use equals to compare, not ==
Others: replace(), split()


Type casting
double num1 = 9.78;
int num2 = (int) num1;                   // Casting Narrowing

String str1 = "123";
int num1 = Integer.parseInt(str1);       // String to int

String str2 = String.valueOf(num1);      // int to String
String str3 = num1 + ""
toString() for Object types

title: Java Basics

Java Basics
text:
Function
public int add(int a, int b) {
    return a + b;
}

Access modifier: public
Return type: int
Method name: add
Parameters: (int a, int b)



reminder: we are still in a class
Method name : camelCase



Void

Indicate that a method does not return any value

public void printIsOdd(int n) {
    System.out.println(n % 2 != 0);
}


Access Modifiers
Methods and Attributes Accessiblility










Modifier
Same Class
Same Package
Subclasses
Everywhere

text:
Compiler

Transform java code into bytecode
Detects syntax and type errors
Optimization
javac MyClass.java ‚û°Ô∏è create file MyClass.class

title: Introduction
text:
JVM







Definition


The Java Virtual Machine (JVM) is the runtime environment for Java programs. It acts as an interpreter between Java code and the operating system.
The JVM :

Executes bytecode
Interacts with OS
Manages Memory (Garbage Collection)






java MyClass ‚û°Ô∏è run main method

title: Introduction
text:
Java Vs Python









Java
Python




Typing
Strongly typed, static
Strongly typed, dynamic


Compilation
Compiled into bytecode
Interpreted


Performance
Very fast
Slower


Syntax
Verbose, requires {}
Concise, uses indentation


Paradigm
Object-oriented
Multi-paradigm


Ecosystem
Huge (Spring, Hibernate‚Ä¶)
Large (Django, Flask, Pandas‚Ä¶)





Typing: int x = 10; vs x = 10
Interpreted: ex√©cution √† la vol√©e
Multi-paradigm (objet, fonctionnel, imp√©ratif)

title: Introduction
text:
Why Java

History / Version

Created in 1991

by James Gosling and Mike Sheridan (Sun Microsystems)

Java 8 (2014) : Lambda, Stream, Optional
Java 17 (2021)
Java 21 (2023)

https://www.java.com/


Facebook story
LTS
2009 Oracle
2017 Java 9 -> Modules
2018 Java 11
Java 17 : Sealed Classes, Refactor JDK




Popular / Mature

Widely used in all sectors
Back-end, Mobile, Big Data
Heavily object-oriented



Enterprise Applications
Backend Development (Spring Boot)
Mobile Development (via Kotlin & Android SDK)
Big Data & Machine Learning




Portability

Compiled to bytecode
Runs on any machine with a JVM
‚ÄúWrite Once, Run Anywhere‚Äù


WORA: desktop, servers, smartphones



Robust / Secure

Automatic memory management
Strong Static Typing
Compile-Time Checks

title: Introduction
text:
Compiler

Transform java code into bytecode
Detects syntax and type errors
Optimization
javac MyClass.java ‚û°Ô∏è create file MyClass.class

title: Introduction
text:
JVM






Definition



The Java Virtual Machine (JVM) is the runtime environment for Java programs. It acts as an interpreter between Java code and the operating system.
The JVM :

Executes bytecode
Interacts with OS
Manages Memory (Garbage Collection)




java MyClass ‚û°Ô∏è run main method


JVM, JDK, JRE

JRE: Java Runtime Environment
JDK: Java Development Kit




Component
Purpose




JVM
Runs Java bytecode


JRE
Contains JVM + libraries to run Java apps


JDK
Includes JRE + compiler + dev tools



https://openjdk.org/projects/jdk/


JRE: java.util, java.io‚Ä¶, $java

to execute java app

JDK: $javac, new libraries

to dev java app

title: Java - TP2

1 Objectives

POO
Introduction to Maven

title: Java - TP2
text:
2 Before you start

2.1 Launch service VSCode Java

Launch the service VScode-Java using this link



2.2 Update your repo






Important



During the first tutorial, you created a fork of the ENSAI-2A-Java-TP repository, i.e.¬†you created a copy of this repository on GitHub.
The original repository has been updated, so you need to synchronise your fork with the latest version of the repository.


Choose one of these two possibilities to perform it :

Using GitHub interface : sync on GitHub, and then clone on your VSCode
Manually : clone on your VSCode, and then sync using git commands


Using GitHub interface (easy way)

Login to GitHub
Open the fork of ENSAI-2A-Java-TP, you created at the first practical
Clic on Sync fork
Open a terminal in VSCode an clone your repo



In a terminal

Open a terminal in VSCode
Clone your repository
Position yourself into the repo using cd <my_repo>
Add the original repository as a remote (call it upstream)

git remote add upstream https://github.com/ludo2ne/ENSAI-2A-Java-TP.git

Fetch the latest changes from upstream

git fetch upstream

Make sure you‚Äôre on the branch main

git checkout main

Merge the changes

git merge upstream/main

Resolve any conflicts (if necessary)
Push the updates to your fork

git push origin main





2.3 Open Folder

File > Open Folder > tp2

tp2 must be the root folder of your explorer.

title: Java - TP2
text:
3 Compile and run

3.1 Maven

mvn clean compile

Drop target folder, Download dependencies, Compile

mvn exec:java

Run main method of Main class

mvn test

Run unit tests

text:
5 Exercices

5.1 Exercice 1
Des tests unitaires ont d√©j√† √©t√© √©crits

dans VSCode √† gauche, cliquez sur l‚Äôicone en forme de fiole

patientez quelques secondes le temps que VSCode trouve les tests unitaires

lancez les tests en cliquant sur les 2 triangles pointants vers la droite
corrigez les tests (voir sujet)

Question 2 :

cr√©ez la classe de tests SpecieTest
√©crivez les TU de la classe Specie en vous inspirant de ce qui a √©t√© fait pour Player
M√©thodes √† tester :

Constructeur de BULBZAURUS
Constructeur de CHARMANDUS
toString() de BULBZAURUS : Species [number=0, name=Bulbzaurus, type=GRASS, initialHp=10, initialStrength=1]




5.2 Exercice 2

cr√©ez la classe InventoryTest et √©crivez les TU de la m√©thode add()
cr√©ez la classe SingleUseItemTest



5.3 Exercice 3
Rappels sur les interfaces :

cr√©ez une Interface Coordinates contenant les m√©thodes communes
